The rising levels of CO2 have resulted in significant environmental challenges. Among the potential solutions, the electrochemical CO2 reduction reaction (eCO2RR) has emerged as a highly effective approach, offering the dual benefits of reducing carbon emissions and supporting sustainable energy production. Of the various possible products, CH4 is regarded as the most ideal outcome of eCO2RR. Consequently, designing and synthesizing high-performance eCO2RR catalysts for CH4 production is of critical importance. In this study, density functional theory (DFT) calculations are utilized to explore the catalytic performance of ten transition metal atoms anchored on Fe2B2 MBene as single-atom catalysts (SACs) for eCO2RR to CH4. The results reveal that Ti-Fe2B2 SAC exhibits excellent electrocatalytic activity and high catalytic selectivity, with a limiting potential of -0.48 V. Furthermore, the electronic properties of Ti-Fe2B2 SAC are analyzed. This work offers valuable insights into MBene-based electrocatalysts for eCO2RR and provides guidance for designing robust catalysts with enhanced activity and selectivity for eCO2RR. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords eCO2RR Fe2B2 MBene CH4 Single-atom catalyst Density function theory Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The excessive reliance on fossil fuels and the rising atmospheric CO2 levels have triggered severe energy crises and environmental pollution [1–4]. Therefore, developing technologies that can efficiently convert CO2 into renewable energy has become increasingly urgent. At present, the main methods for CO2 conversion include electrochemical [5], thermochemical [6], biochemical [7], and photochemical reactions [8–10], among which electrochemical CO2 reduction reaction (eCO2RR) has garnered significant interest due to its favorable operating conditions, exceptional reaction efficiency, and the potential to be powered by renewable energy sources such as solar or wind power [11–15]. eCO2RR can convert CO2 into C1 compounds such as formic acid (HCOOH), methanol (CH3OH), methane (CH4), and carbon monoxide (CO) [16,17], among which CH4, due to its simple structure and high energy density, is considered one of the most attractive target products for eCO2RR. Currently, Cu-based catalysts, as low-cost and highly promising CO2 electroreduction catalysts, can stably reduce CO2 to CH4 [18–21]. However, Cu catalysts face challenges such as high reaction overpotentials (typically above 1 V), poor product selectivity, and a higher tendency to undergo hydrogen evolution reactions (HER) under the same potential [22–24], which limits their practical applications. Therefore, it is crucial to develop cost-effective, readily available, highly selective, active, and stable electrocatalysts for efficient CO2 electroreduction. In recent years, single-atom catalysts (SACs) have gained widespread attention in the area of electrocatalysis due to their excellent catalytic activity, outstanding stability, and high efficiency [25–28]. Among these, two-dimensional materials have become ideal supports for SACs due to their unique structural characteristics, large specific surface areas, and rich active sites [29,30]. For instance, Liu et al. [31]. fabricated SACs by loading transition metal (TM) atoms onto a graphdiyne support and studied their performance in eCO2RR. The study showed that Co-graphdiyne SAC exhibits excellent CH3OH selectivity, with a limiting potential of only −0.31 V, demonstrating superior catalytic performance as an eCO2RR catalyst. Athawale et al. [32]. utilized Ti2CO2 MXene to load transition metal atoms and prepared SACs, finding that Ti-Ti2CO2 SAC could efficiently reduce CO2 to CH4 at a relatively low limiting potential of −0.67 V, showing great potential in electrocatalysis. Wang et al. [33]. demonstrated that Ti-W2CO2 SAC can reduce CO2 to formic acid at a limiting potential of −0.11 V, showcasing exceptional catalytic performance. Additionally, Li et al. [34]. found that Ti2CN2-supported Sc/Ti/V atoms form SACs that can reduce CO2 to carbon monoxide with limiting potentials of −0.37, −0.27, and −0.23 V, respectively. These studies demonstrate that SACs based on two-dimensional materials, especially MXenes as supports, exhibit significant catalytic activity and vast application potential in eCO2RR. Similar to MXenes, MBenes are a class of new two-dimensional nanolayered transition metal boride materials with the general formula MnB2n-2 (where M represents a transition metal, B represents boron, and n = 2, 3, 4) [35] and a great many MBenes have been theoretically proven to be stable [36–39], such as Fe2B2, Cr2B2, Mo2B2, and W2B2. Lately, MBenes have garnered significant attention because of their unique structural features and electrocatalytic properties, and part of the MBenes has been successfully experimentally synthesized [40–42]. MBenes not only have high carrier mobility, high carrier density, and excellent conductivity [43,44], but also exhibit remarkable performance in electrocatalysis. For instance, Li et al. [45]. studied the performance of TiB monolayer materials in hydrogen evolution reactions (HER), finding that TiB monolayers with oxygen groups (TiB-O*) have a hydrogen atom Gibbs free energy (ΔGH*0 = 0.03 eV) close to 0 eV, indicating their potential as excellent HER electrocatalysts. Tian et al. [46]. discovered that Cu-Mo2B2 is an efficient bifunctional catalyst for oxygen evolution reaction/oxygen reduction reaction (OER/ORR), with limiting potentials of −0.31 V and 0.34 V, respectively. Song et al. [47]. showed that Fe2B2 also exhibited outstanding catalytic performance in nitrogen reduction reactions (NRR), with a free energy of 0.02 eV and a limiting potential of −0.44 V. Yao et al. [48]. further investigated the performance of bare Fe2B2 surfaces in eCO2RR, revealing that the reduction of CO2 to methane demands a limiting potential of −0.82 V. However, although there are some studies on MBenes in electrocatalysis, research on the loading of metal atoms on MBene surfaces to form SACs and enhance electrocatalytic activity is still relatively scarce and requires further exploration. Fe is inexpensive and readily available, so compared to other MBene materials, Fe2B2 theoretically offers a lower preparation cost, and it holds promise for large-scale synthesis and practical applications in the future. Therefore, this study, based on density functional theory (DFT) calculations, selects Fe2B2-supported transition metal SACs (TM-Fe2B2) as the research object and systematically investigates the reaction pathways for eCO2RR to generate CH4. Through theoretical screening and analysis, the main goal is to identify more efficient MBene-based electrocatalysts and provide theoretical support for optimizing the eCO2RR process for CH4 production. 2 Computing methods All computational work was carried out utilizing the Dmol3 module within the Materials Studio software suite [49], with detailed computational parameters provided in Table 1 . The Fe2B2 MBene supercell was modeled with a 4 × 4 × 1 unit cell. To eliminate the effects of periodic interlayer interactions, the C-axis dimension of the unit cell was set to 40 Å. The Fe2B2 MBene structure consists of four atomic layers, with its top and side views shown in Fig. 1 . The Gibbs free energy change for each step of the eCO2RR is calculated using the hydrogen electrode model at 298.15 K and 0.1 MPa. The change in free energy is defined as follows: (1) Δ G = Δ E a d s + Δ E Z P E − T Δ S Where ∆Eads is the energy change for the reactants and products during the DFT calculation, ∆EZPE is the zero-point energy difference, and ∆S is the entropy difference between reactants and products. The zero-point energy is determined by aggregating the contributions from all vibrational modes. The potential-determining step (PDS) of the entire eCO2RR process is identified based on the highest ΔG value and the smallest stepwise decrease. The corresponding theoretical limiting potential (UL) is then calculated as: (2) U L = − Δ G m a x / e Where ∆Gmax is the maximum Gibbs free energy change for the eCO2RR process. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Stability of TM-Fe2B2 SACs To examine the stability of TM-Fe2B2 SACs, this study focused on ten transition metals (TM = Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, and Zn) from the fourth-period d-block elements as candidates for single-atom stability analysis. The TM atoms were directly adsorbed onto the Fe2B2 surface at four distinct sites—labeled “1,” “2,” “3,” and “4”—corresponding to positions above the first-layer Fe atom, the second-layer Fe atom, the first-layer B atom, and the second-layer B atom, respectively, as illustrated in Fig. 1. The binding energy (Eb) was used to evaluate the stability of transition metal atoms on the Fe2B2 surface, defined as Eb = Emetal/MBene - EMBene - Emetal, where Emetal/MBene, EMBene and Emetal represent the total energy of the MBene system loaded with the transition metal atom, the energy of the pristine MBene system, and the energy of an isolated transition metal atom, respectively. The binding energy values are presented in Table 2 , and these were further compared to the cohesive energy of the respective metal atoms. The cohesive energy is defined as Cohesive energy = (Ebulk - Emetal * N)/ N, where Ebulk is the energy of the bulk material representing the stable natural state of the metal, Emetal has the same meaning as in the binding energy definition, and N denotes the number of atoms in the bulk structure. As shown in Table 2, the binding energies of the ten transition metal atoms on the Fe2B2 surface are more negative than their corresponding cohesive energies. Furthermore, the binding energies at site "3″ are the most negative among the four sites for all ten transition metals. This indicates that these transition metal atoms can stably exist at site "3″ on the Fe2B2 surface. To gain deeper insights into the interactions of the TM atoms with the Fe2B2 substrate, this study performed TDOS and PDOS analyses on the optimized most stable configurations, as shown in Fig. 2 (using Ti-Fe2B2 as an example) and Fig. S1. Fig. 2a shows that the pseudogap of the substrate increases after metal modification, indicating an enhancement in the covalent nature of the substrate upon single-atom metal modification. The PDOS plot in Fig. 2b reveals that the 3d orbitals of the single Ti atom overlap with the 3d orbitals of Fe atoms on the Fe2B2 surface in the energy range from −7.4 eV to 2.3 eV. This suggests a robust coupling between the Fe2B2 substrate and the single Ti atom. Similarly, analysis of the TDOS and PDOS in Fig. S1 shows that the 3d orbitals of Sc, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu also overlap with the 3d orbitals of Fe atoms on the Fe2B2 surface, further indicating strong bonding between the Fe2B2 substrate and these single atoms. However, for single Zn atoms, there is almost no overlap between the 3d orbitals of Zn and the 3d orbitals of Fe atoms on the Fe2B2 surface, suggesting the bonding between Zn and the Fe2B2 substrate is weaker compared to the other single atoms. The differential charge density of the Ti-Fe2B2 SAC is shown in Fig. 3 . It can be observed that the regions around the Ti atom are predominantly red, while the regions around the Fe atoms are predominantly blue. This indicates electron transfer occurring between the Ti and Fe atoms, with electrons being transferred from the Fe atoms to the Ti atom. This further demonstrates the robust interaction of the Ti atom with the Fe2B2 MBene substrate, confirming that the Ti atom is capable of stably residing on the Fe2B2 MBene surface. A similar behavior is observed for the other TM atoms, as shown in Fig. S2. Next, the dissolution potential (Udiss) of the metal sites was evaluated to assess their electrochemical stability (see Table 2). The Udiss is calculated using the formula: U diss = U diss 0 − E f / e N e , where U diss 0 , Ne , and Ef represent the standard electrode potential of the metal atom, the number of electrons involved in the dissolution process, and the formation energy, respectively. The formation energy Ef is defined as Ef = Emetal/MBene - EMBene - Ebulk/ N. Here, Emetal/MBene, EMBene, Ebulk, and N have the same meanings as in the binding energy (Eb) and cohesive energy formulas. Variations in charge transfer during the dissolution process could result in differences between the calculated and observed Udiss. Consequently, Udiss>0 V was adopted as a threshold to prevent an inaccurate assessment of the candidate materials. As shown in Table 2, only the Udiss of the Sc atom is less than 0 V, indicating that, under electrochemical conditions, all transition metal atoms except Sc can stably exist on the Fe2B2 surface. Thus, in the subsequent investigation, we focused on the eCO₂RR process for TM-Fe2B2 SACs, excluding Sc. 3.2 CO2 adsorption on TM-Fe2B2 SACs Extensive research has demonstrated that CO2 adsorption is a critical step in the eCO2RR process. For the nine selected TM-Fe2B2 SACs, CO2 adsorption can occur in three possible configurations, as illustrated in Fig. 4 : (i) CO2 adsorbed vertically above the TM atom at a distance of 2 Å; (ii) CO2 adsorbed parallel to the TM atom with the carbon atom 2 Å above the TM; and (iii) CO2 adsorbed parallel to the TM atom with the oxygen atom 2 Å above the TM. The optimized adsorption structures of CO2 on TM-Fe2B2 SACs are shown in Figs. 5 and S3. In Fig. 5(i), CO2 adsorbed on the Ti-Fe2B2 SAC shows negligible structural changes after optimization, suggesting weak adsorption. In Fig. 5(ii), while the CO2 molecule deforms after optimization, the TM-C bond length increases significantly (Table S1), indicating that CO2 may not easily adsorb onto the Ti-Fe2B2 surface in this configuration. However, in Fig. 5 (iii), the CO2 molecule undergoes substantial structural changes, with both bond angles and bond lengths showing significant variations. Additionally, the TM-C bond length shortens (Table S1), indicating a strong interaction between CO2 and the Ti-Fe2B2 SAC surface, favoring adsorption in this configuration. Similar behavior is observed for CO2 adsorption on V-Fe2B2, Cr-Fe2B2, Mn-Fe2B2, Fe-Fe2B2, Co-Fe2B2, and Ni-Fe2B2 SACs (Fig. S3 and Table S1). However, for Cu-Fe2B2 and Zn-Fe2B2 SACs, the CO2 molecule exhibits minimal structural changes, with increased TM-C and TM-O bond lengths after optimization. This suggests that CO2 adsorption is weaker on Cu-Fe2B2 and Zn-Fe2B2 SACs, making them less suitable for eCO2RR. The adsorption energy (Eads) of CO2 on TM-Fe2B2 SACs was calculated using the formula: Eads = Esystem - Esubstrate - Eadsorbate, where Esystem, Esubstrate, and Eadsorbate represent the total energy of the system with adsorbed CO2, the energy of TM-Fe2B2, and the energy of CO2, respectively. The values of Eads are listed in Table 3 . Among the configurations, configuration (iii) exhibits the most negative Eads and the highest charge transfer (CT), indicating that CO2 is most likely to adsorb on TM-Fe2B2 surfaces in this configuration. Conversely, the Eads of CO2 on Cu-Fe2B2 and Zn-Fe2B2 SACs surface ranges from −0.13 eV to −0.42 eV, with CT values between 0.05 and 0.22 e, making these surfaces less effective for CO2 activation and unsuitable for eCO2RR. Furthermore, we performed PDOS analysis on the most stable configurations of CO₂ adsorbed on TM-Fe2B2 SACs (Figs. 6 and S4). From Fig. 6, it can be observed that the Ti 3d orbitals overlap with the CO2 orbitals around −10.2 eV and −9 to −2.4 eV, indicating strong interaction between Ti-Fe2B2 SAC and CO2. Similarly, Fig. S4 shows that the 3d orbitals of V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, and Ni atoms also overlap with CO2 orbitals. However, there is negligible overlap between the 3d orbitals of Cu and Zn with CO2, further implying that CO2 activation occurs more effectively on V-Fe2B2, Cr-Fe2B2, Mn-Fe2B2, Fe-Fe2B2, Co-Fe2B2, and Ni-Fe2B2 SACs. In addition, hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) may compete with eCO2RR during the catalytic process, potentially affecting SAC selectivity. Table 3 compares the Eads and CT of H atoms and CO2 on TM-Fe2B2 SACs. The results indicate that CO2 adsorption energy is more negative than that of H adsorption on all TM-Fe2B2 SACs, suggesting that TM-Fe2B2 preferentially adsorbs CO2 over H in competitive scenarios. However, the relatively weak adsorption and low charge transfer for CO2 on Cu-Fe2B2 and Zn-Fe2B2 SACs indicate their unsuitability as eCO2RR catalysts. Therefore, in the subsequent study, only the seven TM-Fe2B2 SACs (TM = Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni) were selected to investigate the eCO2RR process for CH4 production. 3.3 TM-Fe2B2 SACs for eCO2RR to CH4 In the eCO₂RR process for CH4 production, each step involves proton-electron pairs (H ++e -), as represented by the overall electrode reaction in Eq. (3): (3) C O 2 + 8 H + + 8 e − → C H 4 + 2 H 2 O This reaction comprises a total of eight proton and electron transfer steps. In each protonation step, the proton can bind to either the C or O atoms, directly influencing the types of intermediates formed. To elucidate the reaction pathway for eCO2RR to CH4 on TM-Fe2B2 SACs, we performed stepwise hydrogenation optimization starting from the stable CO2 adsorption configurations. The reaction pathway with the lowest Gibbs free energy changes was determined to construct the optimal reaction profile. 3.3.1 Ti-Fe2B2 SAC for eCO2RR to CH4 The Gibbs free energy changes for CO2 reduction to CH4 on the Ti-Fe2B2 SAC are illustrated in Fig. 7 . During the first hydrogenation step, the hydrogen atom could not bind to the carbon atom after optimization but instead bonded to the oxygen atom to form the *OCOH intermediate, with a Gibbs free energy change of +0.44 eV. In the second hydrogenation step, hydrogen can either bond to the oxygen atom, generating *OC with a Gibbs free energy reduction of −0.18 eV, or bond to the carbon atom, forming the *OCHOH intermediate with a Gibbs free energy reduction of −0.15 eV. Since the energy differences are minor, both *OC and *OCHOH were considered for further hydrogenation. When hydrogenation continues on *OC, the intermediate *OCH is formed with a Gibbs free energy reduction of −0.14 eV. Further hydrogenation yields *OCH2 with an additional energy decrease of −0.26 eV. Alternatively, when *OCHOH undergoes further hydrogenation, hydrogen bonding to the oxygen atom results in dehydration, producing *OCH, and subsequent hydrogenation forms *OCH2. Alternatively, hydrogen bonding to the carbon atom generates *OCH2OH, and further hydrogenation produces *OCH2, with Gibbs free energy changes of −0.72 eV and +0.29 eV, respectively. As the pathway *OC → *OCH → *OCH2 exhibits the most favorable energy changes, it is identified as the preferred route. An important observation is that *OCH2 has highly negative adsorption energy on the Ti-Fe2B2 SAC (Table S2), making its desorption difficult. This effectively suppresses the formation of formaldehyde (HCHO) as a byproduct [50]. In the fifth hydrogenation step, hydrogen bonds to the carbon atom to form *OCH3. During the sixth hydrogenation step, Gibbs free energy analysis reveals that hydrogenation at the carbon atom leads to *O and CH4 with an energy decrease of −1.03 eV, whereas hydrogenation at the oxygen atom forms *OHCH3 with an energy increase of +0.63 eV. The unfavorable energy increase for *OHCH3 formation suggests that the sixth hydrogenation step preferentially produces *O and CH4 while avoiding methanol (CH3OH) formation. The seventh and eighth hydrogenation steps convert *O into water (*H2O), completing the reduction of CO2 to CH4 on the Ti-Fe2B2 SAC. The optimal reaction pathway for CO2 reduction to CH4 on the Ti-Fe2B2 SAC is thus: *CO2 → *OCOH → *OC → *OCH → *OCH2 → *OCH3 → *O + CH4↑ → *OH → *H2O, the UL for this pathway is −0.48 V, occurring during the *OH → *H2O step. 3.3.2 Ni-Fe2B2 SAC for eCO2RR to CH4 The Gibbs free energy changes for CO2 reduction to CH4 on the Ni-Fe2B2 SAC are displayed in Fig. 8 . During the first hydrogenation step, the formation of *OCHO is energetically more favorable (−0.75 eV) compared to *OCOH (+0.41 eV). Thus, the initial hydrogenation step preferentially produces the *OCHO intermediate. In the second hydrogenation step, a H atom can bind to the unsaturated O atom of *OCHO to form *OCHOH (+0.98 eV) or to the carbon atom to form *OCH2O (+1.07 eV). Although the free energy change for *OCHOH formation is slightly lower, both pathways are energetically comparable. Consequently, all potential reaction routes from *OCHOH and *OCH2O were explored. For *OCHOH, hydrogenation at the carbon atom produces *OCH2OH (−0.17 eV), followed by dehydration to form *OCH2 (−0.07 eV). Alternatively, hydrogenation at the oxygen atom leads to dehydration, yielding *OCH (−0.46 eV), which subsequently forms *OCH2 upon further hydrogenation (+0.22 eV). For *OCH2O, hydrogenation at the unsaturated oxygen atom produces *OCH2OH (−0.26 eV), and further hydrogenation leads to dehydration and the formation of *OCH2 (−0.07 eV). Since the pathway *OCHOH → *OCH → *OCH2 shows relatively favorable free energy changes, this sequence was identified as the preferred route for the third and fourth hydrogenation steps. It is noteworthy that the *OCH2 intermediate exhibits a strong adsorption energy of −1.58 eV on the Ni-Fe2B2 SAC (Table S2), indicating its low tendency for desorption. This characteristic effectively prevents the formation of formaldehyde (HCHO) as a byproduct. In the fifth hydrogenation step, a hydrogen atom bonds to the carbon of *OCH2, forming *OCH3. During the sixth hydrogenation step, hydrogenation of *OCH3 at the carbon atom results in *O and CH4 (+0.40 eV), while hydrogenation at the oxygen atom yields *OHCH3 (+0.03 eV). The formation of *OHCH3 is energetically more favorable. Additionally, the strong adsorption energy of *OHCH3 on the Ni-Fe2B2 SAC (Table S2) prevents its desorption, thereby avoiding methanol (CH3OH) production. In the seventh step, further hydrogenation of *OHCH3 produces *OH and CH4. The eighth hydrogenation step converts *OH into water, completing the reduction of CO2 to CH4. The optimal reaction pathway for CO2 reduction to CH4 on the Ni-Fe2B2 SAC is: *CO2 → *OCHO → *OCHOH → *OCH2OH → *OCH2 → *OCH3 → *OHCH3 → *OH + CH4↑ → *H2O. The UL for this pathway is −0.98 V, which occurs during the *OCHO → *OCHOH step. 3.3.3 Cr-Fe2B2 SAC for eCO2RR to CH4 The Gibbs free energy changes for the reduction of CO2 to CH4 on the Cr-Fe2B2 SAC are displayed in Fig. 9 . In the first hydrogenation step, *OCHO(−0.68 eV) is more favorably formed than *OCOH (+0.24 eV). Moreover, the formation of *OCHO effectively suppresses the dehydration of *OCOH to CO, thereby minimizing CO generation. During the second hydrogenation step, a hydrogen atom can either bind to the oxygen atom of *OCHO to form *OCHOH (+0.99 eV) or to the carbon atom to form *OCH2O (+0.14 eV). Since the formation of *OCH2O involves a smaller energy change, *OCH2O is the preferred product in this step. In the third hydrogenation step, the saturated carbon atom prevents further hydrogenation there, so the hydrogen atom bonds to the oxygen atom to produce *OCH2OH. In the fourth step, hydrogenation at the oxygen atom leads to the removal of an H2O molecule, forming *OCH2, with a free energy decrease of 0.22 eV. It is worth noting that *OCH2 has strong Eads of −2.47 eV on the Cr-Fe2B2 SAC (Table S2), indicating low desorption tendencies, which effectively prevents the formation of formaldehyde (HCHO). In the fifth hydrogenation step, a hydrogen atom attaches to the carbon of *OCH2, forming *OCH3. During the sixth step, hydrogenation at the carbon atom of *OCH3 results in *O and CH4 (−0.77 eV), while hydrogenation at the oxygen atom produces *OHCH3 (+0.78 eV). The energetically favorable pathway involves the formation of *O and CH4. Subsequently, the seventh and eighth hydrogenation steps transform *O into water, completing the CO2 reduction process to CH4. The optimal reaction pathway for CO2 reduction to CH4 on the Cr-Fe2B2 SAC is *CO2 → *OCHO → *OCH2O → *OCH2OH → *OCH2 → *OCH2 → *O + CH4↑ → *OH → *H2O. The UL for this pathway is −0.53 V, which occurs during the *OH → *H2O step. Additionally, we investigated the Gibbs free energy changes for CO2 reduction to CH4 on V-Fe2B2, Mn-Fe2B2, Fe-Fe2B2, and Co-Fe2B2 SACs (Fig. S5). The reaction pathways for these SACs are largely consistent with that of Cr-Fe2B2. The UL for these SACs, as summarized in Table 4 , occur at different reaction steps: −0.88 V at the eighth step for V-Fe2B2 SAC, −0.70 V at the second step for both Mn-Fe2B2 and Fe-Fe2B2 SACs, and −1.00 V at the second step for Co-Fe2B2 SAC. As shown in Table 4, the UL of Ti-Fe2B2 SAC for eCO2RR is −0.48 V, which is lower than that of V-Fe2B2, Cr-Fe2B2, Mn-Fe2B2, Fe-Fe2B2, Co-Fe2B2, and Ni-Fe2B2, indicating that Ti-Fe2B2 SAC exhibits the best catalytic performance of all the candidates evaluated. Furthermore, it is worth noting that the UL value (−0.48 V) of Ti-Fe2B2 SAC is lower than its Udiss (0.66 V), indicating that under experimental conditions, applying a voltage of 0.48 V for the electrocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction, Ti-Fe2B2 SAC will theoretically not dissolve and is a highly stable electrocatalyst. In addition, the findings of this study were compared with previously published literature, as shown in Table 4. We found that in the eCO2RR process for CH4 synthesis, the UL of Ti-Fe2B2 SAC is more favorable than that of other reported catalysts such as Mo2B2, V-phthalocyanine monolayer, Fe-N4, Mo2C, and Fe2B2, suggesting that Ti-Fe2B2 SAC is an excellent catalyst for eCO2RR CH4 synthesis. Although it's UL is not as low as that of Pt-MoS2 and Ru-Cu(211), Ti-Fe2B2 SAC is more cost-effective than Pt-MoS2 and Ru-Cu(211), making it a highly promising catalyst for eCO2RR. 3.4 Intrinsic mechanism behind the catalytic activity differences of TM-Fe2B2 SACs in eCO2RR for CH4 production The catalytic performance of transition metal catalysts is closely tied to the electronic structure of their surface d-orbitals [57]. In particular, the energy distribution of the d-orbitals determines the interaction between the surface atoms of the catalyst and the reactants. A higher d-band center (nearer to the Fermi level) indicates stronger interactions between the metal's electrons and the reactants, thereby influencing the catalyst's performance [58]. To further elucidate the root cause of the performance differences among these SACs, we calculated the d-band centers of the active single atoms Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, and Ni (Fig. 10 ). As shown in Fig. 10, although the d-band centers of all single atoms lie below the Fermi level (negative values), the d-band center of Ti is located at −0.31 eV, higher than those of V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, and Ni. This suggests that single-atom Ti interacts more readily with the reactants and thus exhibits better catalytic activity. Based on the above analysis, the Ti single atom in the Ti-Fe2B2 SAC, owing to its relatively higher d-band center, interacts more effectively with surface intermediates during the eCO2RR process for CH4 production, thereby achieving superior catalytic performance over other SACs. 4 Conclusions This work employed first-principles calculations to investigate electrochemical CO2-to-CH4 reduction on TM-anchored Fe2B2 MBene SACs. The findings reveal that Ti-Fe2B2, V-Fe2B2, Cr-Fe2B2, Mn-Fe2B2, Fe-Fe2B2, Co-Fe2B2, and Ni-Fe2B2 SACs exhibit stability as electrocatalysts for CO2 reduction to CH4. Among them, the Ti-Fe2B2 SAC demonstrates outstanding CO2-to-CH4 conversion efficiency, featuring a low limiting potential of −0.48 V and effective inhibition of the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). The optimal reduction pathway for CO2 on the Ti-Fe2B2 SAC is as follows: *CO2 → *OCOH → *OC → *OCH → *OCH2 → *OCH3 → *O + CH4 → *OH → *H2O. Additionally, the Ti-Fe2B2 SAC achieves remarkable CH4 selectivity, minimizing by-product formation, including CO, HCHO, and CH3OH. These results highlight the potential of Ti-Fe2B2 SAC as an efficient electrocatalyst, delivering excellent activity and selectivity for eCO2RR to CH4. This study offers key theoretical insights for the design and development of MBene-based electrocatalysts with exceptional catalytic performance and high selectivity for CH4 production in eCO2RR. Although Fe2B2 MBene has been theoretically proven to be stable, its experimental synthesis remains challenging. Nevertheless, we are optimistic and confident that with future breakthroughs in Fe2B2 MBene preparation technology, the current theoretical calculations will be experimentally validated. coredata.dc:description: The rising levels of CO2 have resulted in significant environmental challenges. Among the potential solutions, the electrochemical CO2 reduction reaction (eCO2RR) has emerged as a highly effective approach, offering the dual benefits of reducing carbon emissions and supporting sustainable energy production. Of the various possible products, CH4 is regarded as the most ideal outcome of eCO2RR. Consequently, designing and synthesizing high-performance eCO2RR catalysts for CH4 production is of critical importance. In this study, density functional theory (DFT) calculations are utilized to explore the catalytic performance of ten transition metal atoms anchored on Fe2B2 MBene as single-atom catalysts (SACs) for eCO2RR to CH4. The results reveal that Ti-Fe2B2 SAC exhibits excellent electrocatalytic activity and high catalytic selectivity, with a limiting potential of -0.48 V. Furthermore, the electronic properties of Ti-Fe2B2 SAC are analyzed. This work offers valuable insights into MBene-based electrocatalysts for eCO2RR and provides guidance for designing robust catalysts with enhanced activity and selectivity for eCO2RR.
